Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Microbial Contamination and Treatment in Residences Damaged in the Recent Colorado Flood

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1363427
Miller

The recent floods in and around Boulder, Colorado resulted in at least 4000 damaged residents. One of the side effects of flooded basements or homes is the growth of fungi and bacteria. The growth of these organisms can increase the risk of exposure and possibly have adverse health outcomes. The research team has already obtained a control samples from a set of pre-flood homes. This research project will enable them to conduct similar sample collections post-flood. They will then evaluate the use of full-room disinfection of flooded homes. They intend to use ultraviolet germicidal lights (UV lights) to disinfect the rooms. The results will be presented at the Healthy Buildings 2015 Regional Conference for the Americas and a research paper will be submitted to Indoor Air or related journal. Recommendations for the use of UVGI in flood remediation will be communicated to the appropriate groups (e.g. FEMA, IICRC, NFIP). Through the Discovery Learning Apprentice program in the College of Engineering and Applied Science undergraduate and graduate students will assist in every aspect of this study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the United States, floods are the most common natural disaster, and are predicted to increase in both severity and magnitude with climate change. In September 2013, the Front Range of Colorado experienced a devastating 1000-year rain event resulting in historic flooding that destroyed or damaged as many as 20,000 homes and claimed eight lives. The repercussions of this flood are still being felt and remediation and rebuilding is ongoing. 

Mold growth is common in homes that have flooded and can degrade indoor air quality and human health. Current methods of mold mitigation can be expensive, time consuming, and fail to completely remedy the fungal growth. Disinfection using ultraviolet germicidal irradiation (UVGI) is well proven for inactivating airborne and surface organisms in hospital settings, water treatment, and food sterilization. Less, however, is known about the efficacy of UVGI treatment of flood-impacted structures. In this study, a whole-room disinfection device was operated in seven homes in Boulder County, CO that flooded in September 2013 to determine the effect of treatment on indoor air microbial community composition and indoor air quality, as well as its viability for mitigating mold issues post-flood. Results showed no impact on the fungal and bacterial indoor air DNA concentrations as measured by qPCR.  Swabs of contaminated surfaces showed that there was some reduction in active microbes as measured by colony-forming units especially when the data for all homes were pooled together. Carbon dioxide and particulate matter concentrations varied within and between homes and were not impacted by treatment.
